definition: strike first and gain the upper hand (idiom, martial arts term); Making the first move is an advantage.

sentences.english: Just think of what would happen if one nuclear power launched a preemptive on another .
sentences.chinese: 试想一下一个核年夜国先下手为强会出现什么情况。

sentences.english: Deliver your attack before your opponent begins his.
sentences.chinese: 对手开始攻击前要先下手为强。

sentences.english: “I am a big believer in getting there first, ” he says.
Altai decided tos beat him at his own game, start first for strong, deal with ShaoZheng.
sentences.chinese: 阿尔泰决定将计就计，先下手为强，对付邵正。

definition: to gain the initiative by striking first (idiom); to preempt/to anticipate/preemptive
to cut weeds and eliminate the roots (idiom); to destroy root and branch/to eliminate completely
to beat sb at their own game (idiom)
a blitzkrieg strategy (idiom)/to resolve sth in the shortest time possible/to get sth done quickly
lit. to pull a snake from its hole/to expose a malefactor (idiom)
to lend sb a knife to kill sb/to get sb else to do one's dirty work/to attack using the strength of another (idiom)
a cornered dog will jump over the wall (idiom)/to be driven to desperate action
lit. either the fish dies or the net splits/a life and death struggle (idiom)
lit. quick sword cuts through tangled hemp (idiom); decisive action in a complex situation/cutting the Gordian knot
to sit and wait for death (idiom); resigned to one's fate
to defeat the enemy by capturing their chief (idiom)
don't do it, or don't rest (idiom); either give up, or go through to the end/Since we started, we must carry it through whatever happens./in for a penny, in for a pound
pinyin: yi1 bu4 zuo4 , er4 bu4 xiu1

definition: peaceful measures before using force (idiom); diplomacy before violence/jaw-jaw is better than war-war
lit. to settle accounts after autumn/settle scores at an opportune moment (idiom)
see the opportunity and act (idiom); to act according to circumstances/to play it by ear/to use one's discretion
lit. to nurture a tiger invites calamity/fig. to indulge one's enemy is asking for trouble (idiom)
